docs.lead_paragraph: Countries that do not protect American copyrights, trademarks and patents could be denied tariff concessions by the United States, while American laws would be stiffened to prevent sales of pirated or counterfeit goods here under new Reagan Administration proposals to be announced this week. ''The United States provides strong protection for intellectual property rights within our borders for domestic and foreign citizens and businesses,'' a Presidential policy statement said. ''We expect other nations to do the same in the interest of stimulating increased innovation and improving living standards throughout the world.'' The new program, documents from which have been circulated on a restricted basis and were obtained by The New York Times, envisages domestic legislative initiatives as well as multilateral and bilateral trade-linked actions.

headline.main: U.S. PLANS TO DEFEND ITS PATENTS

docs.snippet: Countries that do not protect American copyrights, trademarks and patents could be denied tariff concessions by the United States, while American laws would be stiffened to prevent sales of pirated or counterfeit goods here under new Reagan...

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: ON CHRISTMAS EVE, 1961, A BOSTON hematologist named Victor Herbert went to bed feeling a little weak. For three months he had been conducting an experiment on himself, attempting to prove that a debilitating condition known as megaloblastic folic acid deficiency anemia could be caused by a diet poor in folic acid. Folic acid, also called folate, is a vitamin that takes its name from the Latin word for leaf, a reflection of its abundance in green leafy vegetables. It is also plentiful in yeast, liver and mushrooms. Folate is present in most foods, in fact, but it is destroyed by heating and other forms of processing. Since October, Herbert had been on a bland diet specially designed for his experiment, and in recent days he had not felt quite up to par. He decided to sleep late on Christmas morning. His wife rose early and went out with the children. She wanted to give her husband a few extra hours of sleep. When he awoke and tried to get out of bed, his legs were so weak they seemed paralyzed.

keywords.value: WHO GOES FIRST?: THE STORY OF SELF-EXPERIMENTATION IN MEDICINE

byline.original: By Lawrence K. Altman; Lawrence K. Altman, M.D., is a medical reporter for The Times. This article has been adapted from his book, ''Who Goes First?: The Story of Self-Experimentation in Medicine,'' planned for publication in 1987 by Random House
